Specific insights on the synergistic role of metal and acid sites of low loading Pd(PVA)/zeolite catalysts for furfural hydrogenation Sara Morandi Writing – original draft Methodology Conceptualization a Maria Pinto Investigation Data curation a Ilaria Barlocco Investigation Data curation b Silvio Bellomi Investigation Data curation b Alberto Villa Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization b ⁎ Maela Manzoli Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization c ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, NIS Center and INSTM Reference Center, University of Torino, Via P. Giuria 7, 10125 Torino, Italy b Department of Chemistry, University of Milano, via Golgi 19, Milano I-20133, Italy Department of Chemistry University of Milano via Golgi 19 Milano I-20133 Italy Department of Chemistry, University of Milano, via Golgi 19, I-20133 Milano, Italy c Department of Drug Science and Technology, NIS Center and INSTM Reference Center, University of Torino, Via P. Giuria 9, Torino 10125, Italy Department of Drug Science and Technology NIS Center and INSTM Reference Center University of Torino Via P. Giuria 9 Torino 10125 Italy Department of Drug Science and Technology, NIS Center and INSTM Reference Center, University of Torino, Via P. Giuria 9, 10125 Torino, Italy ⁎ Corresponding authors. The synergistic role of metal and acid sites in Pd colloids with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) supported on zeolite catalysts was proved in furfural hydrogenation. Pd nanoparticles were prepared using PVA sol-immobilization and deposited on zeolites with different pore size (Y, ZSM-5 and FER) and similar Si/Al ratio to correlate the amount of accessible Brønsted and Lewis acid sites with catalytic activity and selectivity. Catalytic tests at 50 °C showed that Pd/Y is the most active catalyst, achieving 95.0 % conversion after 120 min. The presence of Pd is essential for furfural conversion, with bare zeolites showing minimal activity under the same conditions. Product distribution varies with the type of zeolite, with Pd/Y producing a complex mix including tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) and isopropyl levulinate ester (ILE) as the main product after 120 min, while other catalysts mainly form furfuryl isopropyl ether (FIE). FESEM-EDS, TEM, XPS and FT-IR measurements revealed that the most marked difference between Pd/Y and the other catalysts is the much higher amount of Lewis acid sites. This means that the synergistic effect between Pd and Lewis acidity is the key factor for obtaining THFA and ILE through H2 splitting and double bond activation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Furfural hydrogenation Pd catalysts Zeolite acidity PVA sol-immobilization FT-IR spectroscopy CO and 2,6-dimethylpyridine Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Furfural is an ideal feedstock for the sustainable production of value-added chemicals and biofuels and it is traditionally obtained from renewable lignocellulosic biomass [1–5], with an annual global industrial production reaching three hundred thousand tons [6]. It is one of the top 10 biomass derived platform compounds and due to the presence of multiple unsaturated functional groups, furfural can be transformed into several useful derivatives. Its catalytic selective hydrogenation yields a variety of products, such as furfuryl alcohol (FA), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) [7], 2-methylfuran (2-MF) [8] and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) [9]. The hydrogenation of the carbonyl gives FA and further hydrogenation can result in two different products. The hydrogenolysis of FA forms 2-MF, whereas the hydrogenation of the furan ring forms THFA. FA production accounts for nearly 65 % of derivative market [10] and it is used for the production of resins, or as non-reactive diluent for epoxy resins, a modifier for phenolic and urea resins, a solvent, or precursor for the synthesis of other chemicals [11]. 2-MF as well is an important intermediate in fine chemical, perfume and medical industry [12]. THFA has attracted more attention because of its wide applications, such as its use as solvent in the production of resins and critical building blocks for the synthesis of other specialty chemicals and fuels or fuel additives [2,3]. Also, furfuryl isopropyl ether (FIE) can be obtained from furfural by reductive etherification [6]. FIE is highly stable, it has high energy density and octane number, resulting in a potential gasoline component or fuel additive [13]. Moreover, furfural can be directly converted to a levulinate ester by the domino reaction, involving hydrogenation, hydrolysis, ring-opening and lactonization reactions promoted by both Lewis and Brønsted acids [13–15]. Levulinate esters have been revealed as important platform compounds that can be used as green solvents, due to their low vapor pressures, and fuel additives, because they raise the oxygen content in gasoline, resulting in more complete combustion, lower release of harmful gases and soot formation in engines [16]. The hydrogenation of furfural was studied by employing noble-metal catalysts mainly consisting of Pd [17–20]. Supported Pd are mainly used in the liquid-phase and can produce FA via the η2(C,O)-binding of the aldehyde; 2-MF is easier to form at high temperatures or H2 pressures. The surface properties of the support influence side reactions and catalyst stability and have a direct effect on the activity and selectivity in furfural hydrogenation. Somorjai et al. carried out the hydrogenation of furfural over Pt nanoparticles supported on various mesoporous oxides to define the support effects on the selectivity, finding that the decarbonylation of furfural to furan was dominant [21]. Mikolajska et al. studied the activity of Pt deposited on SiO2, γ-Al2O3, MgO, and TiO2, showing very different activity and selectivity on the different supports [22]. Among the supports, zeolites in the H-form possess Brønsted acidity making these materials possible intermediary in the donation of atomic hydrogen formed on the metal particles and spilled to the zeolite [23]. At about 100–150 °C, Brønsted acid sites also mediate the H-transfer from the solvent, with the formation of acetals as main products [24,25]. In zeolites, the extra-framework aluminum is characterized by Lewis acidity and can be responsible for the activation of double bonds, showing a synergistic effect with Pd in the hydrogenation process [25–27]. Finally, zeolites with different microporous structures could give different shape selectivity [24,28,29]. The direct production of isopropyl levulinate ester starting from furfural encompasses both hydrogenation to FA or FIE and hydrolysis of FIE with the formation of the alkyl levulinate [15]. During such process, opportunely designed bifunctional catalysts are required, which can afford hydrogenation and hydrolysis steps. In this paper, the synergy between metal and acid sites in furfural hydrogenation was investigated. Pd nanoparticles were prepared by sol-immobilization and deposited on zeolites with different pore size and similar Si/Al ratio. In particular, to correlate the amount of accessible Brønsted and Lewis acid sites with activity and selectivity for furfural hydrogenation, a large-pore zeolite (Y, with Faujasite FAU structure), a medium-pore zeolite (ZSM-5, with MFI structure) and a medium/small-pore zeolite (Ferrierite, FER structure) were chosen. Moreover, ZSM-5 with a much higher Si/Al ratio was also considered to modify the amount of acid sites not only by pore size limitation. To limit the H-transfer from the solvent mediated by Brønsted acidity, catalytic tests were run at low temperature, i.e. 50 °C, using molecular H2 and 2-propanol as solvent. 2-propanol is one of the most used solvents for furfural hydrogenation because of the high solubility of furfural in this solvent [10,30,31]. Moreover, the possibility of 2-propanol to react with furfural allows the production of high-value products such as ethers and levulinates [32–35]. The relative amount of available Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was determined by 2,6-dimethylpyridine (2,6-DMP) adsorption followed by FT-IR spectroscopy. This probe molecule was chosen due to its steric hindrance similar to that of furfural. Finally, the adsorption of CO followed by FT-IR spectroscopy, and XPS measurements were employed to characterize the metal sites exposed at the surface of the supported Pd nanoparticles. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Na2PdCl4 (99.99 % purity, Sigma-Aldrich), polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) (Mw = 13000–23000, 87–89 % hydrolyzed, Sigma-Aldrich), 2-propanol (≥ 99.5 % purity, Sigma-Aldrich) and NaBH4 (purity > 96 %, Fluka) were used. Gaseous hydrogen from SIAD were 99.99 % pure. Y, ZSM-5 and FER zeolites were provided by Zeolyst International. The zeolites, provided in ammonium-form, were calcined at 500 °C for 6 h to obtain the corresponding H-form. Structural and textural properties of the commercial zeolites are summarized in Table 1. The corresponding pore size distributions are reported in Fig. 1. The two ZSM-5 samples with Si/Al ratio of 15 and 40 will be named ZSM-5(15) and ZSM-5(40), respectively. For FT-IR measurements, CO (99.99 % purity) from Nippon Gases and 2,6-dimethylpyridine (≥ 99.99 % purity) from Sigma-Aldrich were used. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Supported Pd nanoparticles were prepared by using a standard sol-immobilization procedure [36]. Pd(II) salt (0.051 mmol of Na2PdCl4 Sigma-Aldrich, purity > 99.9 %) was dissolved in 0.1 L of water and sequentially 1 mL of 1 wt% polyvinyl alcohol solution (Pd/PVA mass ratio 1:0.5 wt/wt) was introduced. The as obtained yellow solution was maintained under vigorous magnetic stirring for 3 min, then a volume of 0.1 M NaBH4 solution was injected to obtain a Pd/NaBH4 molar ratio equal to 1:8 mol/mol. Immediately, the solution assumed a brown coloration, indicating the formation of Pd(0) colloid. After a few minutes, sulfuric acid was added to adjust the pH to 2 and then the solid support was dispersed in the vigorously stirring colloid. The amount of support was selected to achieve a final palladium loading of 1 wt% (on the assumption of a quantitative metal uptake on the support). After filtration and washing with distilled water to remove Na+ and Cl- and the excess of PVA, the catalysts were dried at 100 °C for 120 min. Metal content was verified by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) using a Perkin Elmer 3100 and the real Pd content was as the nominal one. The prepared catalysts were denoted as Pd/Y, Pd/ZSM-5(15), Pd/ZSM-5(40) and Pd/FER. 2.3 Methods 2.3.1 Catalytic tests Furfural hydrogenation was performed at 50 °C, using a stainless-steel reactor (30 mL capacity), equipped with heater, mechanical stirrer, gas supply system and thermometer. Furfural solution (15 mL; 0.3 M in 2-propanol) was added into the reactor and the desired amount of catalyst (furfural/metal ratio = 500 mol/mol) was suspended in the solution. The pressure of the hydrogen was 5 bar. The mixture was set at 50 °C and mechanically stirred (1250 rpm). At the end of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. Samples were removed periodically (0.2 mL) and HP 7820 A gas chromatograph equipped with a capillary column HP-5 30 m x 0.32 mm, 0.25 µm Film, by Agilent Technologies, was employed. Authentic samples were analyzed to determine separation times. Quantitative analysis with an external standard method (n-octanol) was used. The mass balances were calculated for all catalysts and reported in Table SM-1 of the Supplementary Material. Identification of products was performed using a Thermo Scientific Trace ISQ QD Single Quadrupole GC-MS equipped with a capillary column HP-5 30 m x 0.32 mm, 0.25 µm Film, by Agilent Technologies. Furfural conversion (%) was calculated as follows: Mol of furfural converted Initial mol of furfural x 100 whereas selectivity was obtained by applying the following equation: Mol of product Mol of furfural converted x 100 The initial activity (IA) was calculated by applying the following equation: IA= (molfurfural)×conversion×hour−1/(gPd); or, starting from the XPS Pd molar % that considers the surface metal active sites: IA= (molfurfural)×conversion×hour−1/(Pd molar %). 2.3.2 Characterization techniques Gas-volumetric analyses were performed by N2 adsorption/desorption experiments at liquid nitrogen temperature by means of an ASAP 2020 instrument (Micromeritics) to determine both the specific surface area (BET model) [37] and porosity (DFT model) [38] of the samples. Before the adsorption/desorption experiments, the samples (0.070–0.080 g) were submitted to a thermal treatment (under outgassing for 2 h at 300 °C) to remove the adsorbed water. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) measurements were performed by using a TESCAN S9000G FESEM 3010 microscope (30 kV), equipped with a high brightness Schottky emitter. Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) analysis was carried out thanks to a Ultim Max Silicon Drift Detector (SDD, Oxford, Abingdon-on-Thames, UK). The samples were deposited on stubs coated with a conducting adhesive and inserted into the chamber by a motorized procedure. All samples were submitted to Cr metallization (ca. 5 nm) using an Emitech K575X sputter coater (Quorumtech, Laughton, East Sussex, UK) to avoid charging effects. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) measurements were carried out with a Jeol JEM 3010-UHR instrument operating at 300 kV and equipped with a LaB6 filament. Digital micrographs were acquired by a Gatan (2k x 2k)-pixel Ultrascan1000 CCD camera and processed by Gatan digital micrograph. Before the measurements, to obtain a good dispersion of the samples and to avoid any modification induced using a solvent, the powders were contacted with the Cu grids coated with lacey carbon, resulting in the adhesion of some particles by electrostatic interactions. Pd particle size distributions were obtained by measuring more than 1000 particles on the TEM images and the mean particle diameter (dm) was calculated as dm = Σdini/Σni, where ni was the number of particles of diameter di. Based on each particle size distribution and assuming nanoparticles with hemispherical shape, the corresponding Pd Specific Surface Area (Pd SSA, m2/g) was calculated by applying the formula: 3Σniri 2/(ρPdΣniri 3) m2/g, where ri is the mean radius of the size class containing ni particles and ρPd the volumetric mass of Pd (12.02 g/cm3). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed with a Thermo Scientific K-alpha+ spectrometer. The samples were analysed using a monochromatic Al X-ray source operating at 72 W, with the signal averaged over an oval-shaped area of 600 × 400 μ. Data were recorded at 150 eV for survey scans and 40 eV for high-resolution (HR) scans with a 1 eV and 0.1 eV step size, respectively. CASAXPS (v2.3.17 PR1.1) was used to analyse the XPS raw data. FT-IR spectra were collected in transmission mode with a Perkin-Elmer FT-IR system 2000 spectrophotometer equipped with a Hg-Cd-Te cryodetector, working in the range of wavenumbers 7200–580 cm−1 at a resolution of 2 cm−1 (number of scans 60). For IR analysis, the powder samples were pelletized in self-supporting disks (15–20 mg/cm2) and placed in a home-made quartz IR cell allowing thermal treatments in vacuum or in controlled atmosphere and the recording of the spectra at RT. To characterize the nature of the sites exposed at the surface of Pd particles and support the XPS results, CO adsorption at RT and increasing pressure up to 20 mbar was followed by FT-IR spectroscopy after pre-treatment in vacuum at 100 °C for 1 h [39–42]. The pre-treatment temperature was chosen for desorbing molecular water from the surface without altering the PVA chains and the exposed Pd sites. For the characterization of the Brønsted and Lewis acid site accessibility of the zeolite supports, after the pre-treatment in vacuum at 100 °C, interaction with 2,6-dimethylpyridine (2,6-DMP) at RT was performed. FT-IR spectra were run after admission of 2,6-DMP vapor pressure (ca. 8 mbar) and subsequent outgassing for removing physisorbed (liquid-like) 2,6-DMP. In the Figures, each FT-IR spectrum is reported as difference from the spectrum recorded at RT after the pre-treatment in vacuum at 100 °C. In this way, surface species formed by interaction with probe molecules are better put in evidence. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity and selectivity Fig. 2 shows the percentages of furfural conversion at 50 °C as a function of time for the zeolites with and without palladium. It is evident that Pd is mandatory to obtain furfural conversion at low temperatures [17–20]. The bare zeolites show conversions that remain below 12 % after 120 min, with selectivity above 95.0 % for acetal ( Scheme 1), which denotes the role of Brønsted acid sites [27]. In the presence of Pd, the Pd/Y catalyst is the most active, reaching a conversion of 95.0 % after 120 min. Conversion profiles for Pd/ZSM-5(15), Pd/FER and Pd/ZSM-5(40) are very similar, reaching furfural conversion of 72.0 %, 67.8 % and 61.6 %, respectively, after 120 min. Mass balances for all catalysts at different reaction times have been calculated and reported in Table SM-1 of the Supplementary Material along with the data employed to build Fig. 2. The mass balance closes in all cases except for the most active Pd/Y catalyst at high reaction time (60 and 120 min), likely due to the formation of humines. The distributions of products for the Pd/zeolite samples, built on the data reported in Table SM-1, are shown in Fig. 3. For Pd/Y (Fig. 3A), product distribution is complex and quite different with respect to that of the other samples. After 15 min, the main product is acetal (red trace), whose concentration decreases with time, while furfuryl isopropyl ether (FIE, magenta trace) [6] and furfuryl alcohol (FA, black trace) [8] show bell-shaped trends with maximum after 30 and 60 min, respectively, due to the conversion into tetrahydrofurfuryl isopropyl ether (THFIE, orange trace) and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA, dark gray trace) [9], according to Scheme 1. Finally, the hydration/esterification of FIE leads to the formation of isopropyl levulinate ester (ILE, light gray trace) [2,13–15]. Interestingly, THFA (dark gray trace) is the main product after 120 min, along with a remarkable amount of ILE. For the other samples, the acetal amount after 15 min of reaction follows the order: Pd/ZSM-5(15) > Pd/ZSM-5(40) > Pd/FER and then decreases with time, while the FIE amounts show a reverse trend and increase with time in a specular way with respect to acetal decrease. The main product at 120 min of reaction is FIE, whose amount follows the order: Pd/FER > Pd/ZSM-5(40) > Pd/ZSM-5(15). Indeed, FIE can be obtained through the initial formation of acetal (red traces), i.e. via the direct reaction of furfural with two molecules of 2-propanol, followed by the further removal of one molecule of 2-propanol (see Scheme 1) [2,32,43]. Furthermore, FA (black traces) formation after 120 min follows the order: Pd/ZSM-5(15) ∼ Pd/ZSM-5(40) > Pd/FER. For Pd/ZSM-5(15) (Fig. 3B), the FA amount decreases with time due to THFA formation (dark gray trace), whose increasing trend is correlated to the decreasing trend of FA. For these three catalysts the formation of other products remains under 10 %. Thus, the activity of Pd/ZSM-5(15), Pd/ZSM-5(40) and Pd/FER is limited to the first steps of the reaction chains highlighted by the pale blue square in Scheme 1, while Pd/Y is the only catalyst able to push the reactivity and form THFA and ILE. In this frame, the one-pot synthesis of alkyl levulinates starting from furfural over tailored bifunctional catalysts represents a more economical process with simplified flow. Indeed, alkyl levulinates are usually obtained from levulinic acid esterification with alcohol, in which levulinic acid is produced from furfural or 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, in the latter case requiring one formic acid removal with consequent low atom utilization [15,44–46]. Hence, to understand the catalytic driving forces, a detailed characterization of the Pd phase and acidity of the zeolite supports is reported in the following. 3.2 Characterization of the supported Pd nanoparticles Preliminary FESEM characterization was performed to have information on the overall Pd dispersion of the metal nanoparticles supported on different zeolites and the results are shown in Fig. 4. Images were acquired in BSE mode to maximize the difference of contrast between the metal and the support and therefore observe the Pd nanoparticles as white spots on the darker zeolitic support. The measurements put in evidence high and similar Pd dispersion on Pd/Y (panel A) and on the two Pd/ZSM-5 zeolites (panels B and C): on these catalysts metal nanoparticles with size ranging between 2 and 7 nm were observed (see also the Pd particle size distributions (PSD) in Figure SM-1). As for Pd/FER, besides the presence of nanoparticles with comparable size (4–7 nm, Figure SM-1), metal agglomerates (20–120 nm, Figure SM-2) were also detected (panel D). To get more detailed insights on Pd dispersion, TEM and HR-TEM measurements were performed on selected samples: the Pd/Y sample was chosen because it is the most active catalyst based on the catalytic results reported in Fig. 2, whereas Pd/FER was chosen due to the different Pd dispersion despite its behavior similar to the Pd/ZSM-5 samples in terms of either conversion or selectivity, according to Figs. 2 and 3. TEM and HR-TEM images of Pd/Y are shown in Fig. 5 along with the corresponding Pd PSD. The diameter of most Pd particles is in the range 3–6 nm. PSD is characterized by a mean particle size (dm) of 4.7 nm with a standard deviation of 3.9 nm and a Pd SSA equal to 43.5 m2/g. On the other hand, Pd/FER differs from the other catalysts, showing both large agglomerates of Pd particles ( Fig. 6A) and regions with few isolated nanoparticles (Fig. 6 panels B and C), as previously observed by FESEM measurements. In some regions, particle dispersion is very similar to that observed for the other samples (Fig. 6 panels D and E). PSD, obtained by measuring only isolated particles and excluding agglomerates, is characterized by dm= 4.4 ± 1.8 nm, which results in a Pd SSA of 25.3 m2/g. As reported in the Experimental section, the measured particles for Pd/Y are more than 1000; otherwise, for Pd/FER catalyst, the measured particles are about 500, since particles in agglomerates are not measurable. Isolated particles show PSD with mean size similar to those of the other sample. In general, the sol-immobilization method gives small size and homogeneously dispersed supported metal particles thanks to the pre-formation of Pd colloidal solution and the use of PVA as protective agent. FER zeolite is an exception, giving rise to large Pd particle agglomerates. As for the formation of metal agglomerates on Pd/FER, we tried to shed light on the reason for the peculiar behavior of this sample by analyzing the FT-IR spectra of the catalysts and the corresponding zeolitic supports submitted to the pre-treatment in vacuum at 100 °C for 1 h. The aim was to investigate the possible role of the protecting agent in the interaction between the Pd(PVA) colloids and the different supports. In Figure SM-3 the FT-IR spectra of Pd/Y (black trace), Pd/ZSM-5(15) (blue trace), Pd/ZSM-5(40) (red trace) and Pd/FER (magenta trace) are reported as difference from the spectrum recorded on the corresponding support and compared in the 1500–1310 cm−1 range related to the PVA bending modes of the CH2 groups. The spectrum of PVA in KBr (orange trace) is also reported for the sake of comparison. When the PVA is used to form Pd colloids the absorptions assigned to the CH2 groups appear higher in intensity with respect to the bare polymer and the component at 1453 cm−1 is red shifted and contributes to the band at 1387 cm−1. These features could be taken as an indication that the mobility of the chains is decreased with respect to those of bare PVA, presumably as a result of the interaction between the polymer and the zeolite surface. In the case of Pd/FER (magenta trace) the band at 1387 cm−1 shows the lowest intensity, which means that such interaction is the weakest and could explain the formation of Pd nanoparticle agglomerates. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected to understand catalyst surface chemistry and oxidation states of supported Pd. Surface chemical species, their concentration and overall elemental composition are summarized in Table 2. The data show that the highest surface concentration of Pd was found for Pd/Y (0.78 %), followed by Pd/ZSM-5 samples (0.62 %) and Pd/FER (0.52 %). A significant amount of C (20–42 %) was detected on all the catalyst surfaces, reasonably due to the presence of PVA. High resolution XP spectra of Pd 3d revealed two main species, metallic (reduced) and oxidized Pd (Table 2; Figure SM-4 of the Supplementary Material) in B.E. range of 334.6–335.1 eV and 336.0–337.3 eV, respectively [47,48]. For all catalysts similar fractions of reduced Pd0 and oxidized Pdn+ (where 1 ≤n ≤ 2) were detected. Sites exposed at the surface of Pd particles were studied by CO adsorption at RT followed by FT-IR spectroscopy. Spectra of CO adsorbed at increasing pressure up to 20 mbar on the different Pd/zeolite catalysts are reported in Fig. 7. The bands in the spectra are all related to carbonyls of Pd in different oxidation states. On one hand, it is well evident that the spectra of CO on Pd/Y (panel A), Pd/ZSM-5(15) (panel B) and Pd/ZSM-5(40) (panel C) catalysts show very similar features in terms of band positions and intensities. On the other hand, spectra of CO adsorbed on Pd/FER sample (panel D) differ from those obtained for the other catalysts. In particular, band intensities are lower, revealing lower accessibility of Pd sites. This agrees with the results obtained by FESEM and TEM images: the presence of Pd particle agglomerates on Pd/FER sample justifies the lower accessibility of Pd sites. As for Pd carbonyls, bands at 2175–2150 cm−1 and 2140–2120 cm−1 are assigned to carbonyls of Pd2+ and Pd+, respectively. The absorption at 2100 cm−1 is assigned to CO linearly bonded to Pd0 sites, whereas the envelope of bands in the region 2000–1850 cm−1 is related to bridged carbonyls of Pd0 [39,40,49,50]. Therefore, both XPS and FT-IR measurements showed that, even if Pd particles were previously reduced by Na(BH4), at particle surface relevant amounts of Pd sites were oxidized by air exposure. Moreover, the presence of PVA revealed by C atoms detected by XPS does not affect the accessibility of the Pd sites by the CO probe. Catalytic tests put in evidence the fundamental role of Pd for obtaining furfural conversion. Pd phase characterization by TEM, XPS and FT-IR measurements evidenced similar features for Pd on Y and ZSM-5 supports. Pd/FER differs from the other catalysts in terms of Pd site accessibility, because of the presence of Pd particle agglomerates. However, from the catalytic point of view Pd/FER shows behavior similar to that of Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts; the behavior of Pd/Y differs from the others. This means that Pd is fundamental, but the catalytic behavior is driven by the synergy with zeolite acidity, which can be differently modulated by different pore sizes and Si/Al ratio, as reported in the following. 3.3 Characterization of zeolite Brønsted and Lewis acid sites 2,6-DMP is a sterically hindered mild base that was chosen to verify the accessibility of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites inside the different porosity of the zeolites [51,52]. Steric hindrance of 2,6-DMP is similar to that of furfural and channel apertures of zeolites may hinder reaching acid sites by the reactant. By choosing a large-pore zeolite (Y), a medium-pore zeolite (ZSM-5) and a medium/small-pore zeolite (FER), the aim was to consider the role of Brønsted and Lewis acidity in activity and selectivity for furfural hydrogenation. 2,6-DMP can receive proton from acid OH groups of the zeolite or bond Lewis acid sites, e.g. extra-framework Al3+ cations, through the electron pair of nitrogen: protonated and Lewis-bonded 2,6-DMP molecules show some stretching modes of the aromatic ring in the range 1680–1620 cm−1 and 1620–1550 cm−1, respectively [53–56]. In Fig. 8, spectra of 2,6-DMP obtained after adsorption and outgassing at RT on the different catalysts are compared in the region 1680–1550 cm−1. Spectra were run after outgassing to remove liquid-like 2,6-DMP from the surface. The presence of absorption bands in the two spectral regions evidenced in Fig. 8 is diagnostic of the formation of protonated and Lewis-bonded 2,6-DMP and, consequently, of the presence of both Brønsted and Lewis acidity. The spectrum of 2,6-DMP adsorbed on Pd/Y shows a band (marked with asterisk) that is related to a small amount of residual liquid-like 2,6-DMP [54]. Figure SM-5 of the Supplementary Material compares spectra of 2,6-DMP adsorbed on the zeolites with and without Pd, putting in evidence that Pd does not significantly modify the amount and distribution of accessible acid sites. This finding agrees with the presence of Pd on the external surface of the zeolite and evidence that the partially oxidized Pd sites detected by XPS do not behave as Lewis acid sites. The integrated intensities of the bands in Fig. 8 (see Table 3) are taken as indication of the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites reached by 2,6-DMP. The amount of Brønsted acid sites follows the order: Pd/Y > Pd/ZSM-5(15) > Pd/ZSM-5(40) > Pd/FER; the amount of Lewis acid sites follows the order: Pd/Y > > Pd/ZSM-5(15) ∼ Pd/ZSM-5(40) > Pd/FER. Considering the samples with the same Si/Al ratio (Pd/Y, Pd/ZSM-5(15), Pd/FER), reasonably, the formation of protonated and Lewis-bonded 2,6-DMP is only limited by channel apertures and the orders reported above are in agreement with the decrease of zeolite channel apertures from Y to FER (see Table 1). Accessibility of ZSM-5(40) channels is the same of that of ZSM-5(15), thus, as expected, the lower amount of Brønsted acid sites detected by 2,6-DMP for Pd/ZSM(40) catalyst (Fig. 8, red trace) with respect to Pd/ZSM(15) catalyst (Fig. 8, blue trace) is related to lower Si/Al ratio, i.e. to lower amount of acid OH groups. Otherwise, the two ZSM-5-based catalysts show similar amounts of Lewis acid sites, revealing higher percentage of extra-framework Al3+ for the zeolite with lower aluminum content. 3.4 Effect of the catalyst features on the reactivity To discuss more in depth the catalytic trends observed for the different catalysts, the activity and characterization data are summarized in Table 3. The initial activity (IA) was calculated by considering both the overall amount of Pd (g) and the surface Pd molar % obtained by XPS measurements, respectively. In the former case, Pd/Y converted 2.23 moles of furfural ×hour−1/(gPd), whereas in the latter one the converted moles are 2.86 ×hour−1/(Pd molar %). When considering Pd/FER, these values are 1.59 ×hour−1/(gPd) and 3.06 ×hour−1/(Pd molar %). Based on FESEM Pd particle size distribution (Figure SM-1, panel D), the Pd sites of this catalyst are exposed at the surface of particles with size very similar to the other samples. Despite the presence of the Pd particle agglomerates, Pd/FER retains an activity comparable to the Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts. This means that, considering the activity calculated on surface Pd (Pd molar %), the single metal sites are even more active than those exposed on all other samples. The effect of the PVA protecting agent on Pd properties and activity was investigated (Figure SM-3). A decreased mobility of the polymer chains was assessed to occur upon interaction between the polymer and the zeolite surface. It can be reasonably proposed that the stronger the interaction the higher the accessibility of Pd sites. Indeed, in the case of Pd/FER such interaction is the weakest, explaining, along with presence of Pd particle agglomerates, the lower Pd accessibility probed by CO adsorption. Catalytic tests showed that Pd/Y is the only catalyst able to push reactivity until to form THFA and ILE. The most marked difference between Pd/Y and the other catalysts is the much higher amount of Lewis acid sites (Table 3). This means that the synergistic effect between Pd and Lewis acidity is the key factor for obtaining THFA and ILE through H2 splitting and double bond activation according to Scheme 1. The other three catalysts showed similar furfural conversions, but different selectivity (Figs. 2 and 3 and Table SM-1). In particular, the FIE amount after 120 min follows the order: Pd/FER (75.0 %) > Pd/ZSM-5(40) (58.3 %)> Pd/ZSM-5(15) (46.3 %). Brønsted acid site availability follows the reverse trend. Moreover, FA formation after 120 min follows the order: Pd/ZSM-5(15) (20.3 %) ∼ Pd/ZSM-5(40) (21.4 %) > Pd/FER (12.2 %). Lewis acid site availability displays the same trend. This means that: (i) Pd sites are able to catalyze acetal and FIE formation without the intermediation of Brønsted acid sites for H-transfer; (ii) the synergistic effect between Pd and Lewis acid sites catalyzes furfural hydrogenation into FA, limiting FIE formation. 4 Conclusions Supported Pd nanoparticles were prepared using a sol-immobilization method with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as stabilizing agent. The resulting Pd colloid was deposited on zeolites with different pore size (Y, ZSM-5 and FER) and similar Si/Al ratio to correlate the amount of accessible Brønsted and Lewis acid sites with catalytic activity and selectivity. Moreover, ZSM-5 with a much higher Si/Al ratio was also considered to modify the amount of acid sites not only by pore size limitation. Catalytic tests were conducted for furfural hydrogenation at 50 °C to avoid H-transfer from the solvent (2-propanol). Pd/Y shows the highest conversion (95.0 % after 120 min), while the other catalysts achieve conversions in the range 62–72 %. The product distribution also differs, with Pd/Y producing tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) and isopropyl levulinate ester (ILE) as main products, while Pd/ZSM-5 and Pd/FER primarily produced furfuryl ether (FIE) and acetal. FESEM and TEM measurements revealed that Pd particle dispersion is very similar for the different samples, although Pd/FER exhibits agglomerates. XPS data showed a mixture of metallic and oxidized Pd species on all catalysts. FT-IR spectra of adsorbed CO indicated that Pd/Y, Pd/ZSM-5(15), and Pd/ZSM-5(40) have similar Pd site accessibility, while Pd/FER shows lower accessibility due to agglomerated Pd particles. The accessibility of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was studied by 2,6-dimethylpyridine adsorption followed by FT-IR spectroscopy. Pd/Y shows the highest amount of Lewis acid sites, which was linked to its catalytic activity and selectivity, enabling the formation of THFA and ILE via a synergistic effect between Pd and Lewis acidity. Pd/Y is the only catalyst able to push the reactivity and form THFA and ILE, while the selectivity of Pd/ZSM-5(15), Pd/ZSM-5(40) and Pd/FER is limited to the first steps of the reaction chains. The results obtained for these last catalysts demonstrated that Pd alone is able to catalyze acetal and FIE formation without the intermediation of Brønsted acid sites for H-transfer and that the synergistic effect between Pd and Lewis acid sites catalyzes furfural hydrogenation into furfuryl alcohol (FA), limiting FIE formation. Structure-activity relationships established in this study provide new insights on the one-pot synthesis of alkyl levulinates starting from furfural over tailored bifunctional catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The synergistic role of metal and acid sites in Pd colloids with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) supported on zeolite catalysts was proved in furfural hydrogenation. Pd nanoparticles were prepared using PVA sol-immobilization and deposited on zeolites with different pore size (Y, ZSM-5 and FER) and similar Si/Al ratio to correlate the amount of accessible Brønsted and Lewis acid sites with catalytic activity and selectivity. Catalytic tests at 50 °C showed that Pd/Y is the most active catalyst, achieving 95.0 % conversion after 120 min. The presence of Pd is essential for furfural conversion, with bare zeolites showing minimal activity under the same conditions. Product distribution varies with the type of zeolite, with Pd/Y producing a complex mix including tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) and isopropyl levulinate ester (ILE) as the main product after 120 min, while other catalysts mainly form furfuryl isopropyl ether (FIE). FESEM-EDS, TEM, XPS and FT-IR measurements revealed that the most marked difference between Pd/Y and the other catalysts is the much higher amount of Lewis acid sites. This means that the synergistic effect between Pd and Lewis acidity is the key factor for obtaining THFA and ILE through H2 splitting and double bond activation.

coredata.dc:title: Specific insights on the synergistic role of metal and acid sites of low loading Pd(PVA)/zeolite catalysts for furfural hydrogenation
